author: wims
title: WIMS Cardano Girls Education
description: Girl education in Africa is very low due to poverty, cultural gender preferences, religious beliefs and due to lack of resources. Cardano lacks firm roots in Africa and worse lacks utility value.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is beautiful proposal, but it was quite challenging to dissect for the readability was a bit hard. Word of advice to proposers, for future iteration, please do take more notice on readability, perhaps further attending Catalyst School workshop would be beneficial. Please understand some of the Proposal Assessors go through around 100+ submissions. It is quite a taxing job and we take our efforts very seriously.

With that said, this proposal seeks to empower women to be able to code on Cardano. The extent of the capability of their coding though is limited only to have created wallets (I assume creating an account and not a wallet itself), moved assets and learn about IT security and cryptography. The intended outcome of this proposal is low. From what is explained it does not actually provide applicable skills to build on Cardano.

It would seem that this course is only a basic introduction into Cardano although the proposer has gone into lengths to explain the syllabus that they would design. There is a confusing disconnect between the weight of the program and the intended outcome.
f6_assessments.q1:
One of the proposer have a strong background in education, specifically related to Cardano for they are graduates of Plutus Pioneer cohort 1, 2, and 3. This is very impressive for there are numerous reports on the difficulty of this program. The drop-rate is also high for the Plutus Pioneer program. Graduating from 3 cohorts itself deserves a massive round of applause.

Though from what is stated in the proposal it does not translate well into a comprehensive and understanding action plan. The proposer attempts to address simplifying the Plutus Pioneer program so that it can accomodate newbies of Cardano. The simplified syllabus only goes for 1 (one) week. From what I understand, this course is extremely hard, and to be condensed into only 1 (one) week of training is asking the students and the educators too much.

It would be best practice prior to launching this program and it's syllabus, to first have a test-trial within the Cardano community. For there is a community that has developed a syllabus to educate on Plutus in a project based learning system. This project based learning system is created by Gimbalabs, and to my understanding it is open-source. Even if the proposer is reluctant to use Gimbalabs materials, they can collaborate with Gimbalabs to find insights that perhaps can ease the work of the proposers.
f6_assessments.q2:
From the information provided, there are many holes that need to be addressed. Some of these holes I have gone over lightly in my assessment above this.

From my understanding, there might be a chance of oversimplifying the education material learnt from the Plutus Pioneer program. This can be detected by the output expectations of the students participating in this program. From what is shared, the students will have limited applicable skills to build on Cardano, for they are only expected to produce 2 (two) smart contracts. It does feel like a stop and go program where although there is effort to address continuation, there is not solid plan on it.

The proposers also although consider the risk of having no/limited number of students due to the prerequisites to attend these classes. There is limited effort to explain in detail how to mitigate this. Which is key for it effects their main metric of producing 100+ girls that can create smart contracts.

f6_assessments.q0: The impact of the proposal is clear and compatible with the challenge and Catalyst’s goals. On the other side, the proposal gives an extensive list of risks that it might face, but they didn’t consider a very common risk in such ideas of clubs and courses tailored to a certain group: the risk of not having enough students enrolled or the high chance of drop out. Anyone who has experience with educational programs is aware of this issue. Therefore, foreseen the main risks involved and representing them in the proposal would make it stronger in the impact section.
f6_assessments.q1: This proposal leaves open one question, that is how will they make sure that they will be able to reach their targets? To assess the feasibility of the proposal, it would be necessary to have a contingency plan in case they don’t have enough students interested or fully participating in the clubs. In addition, the budget has some unclear points. For example, the proposals say that they require 13500 USD for a “3 Girls support Materials and Incentives”. However, the proposal does not explain what are these incentives, nor why it applies only for 3 girls, if their target is more than 100. And this part of the budget is more than half of total budget. Therefore, the execution of the budget and the plan could be improved if they provide more details on what was pointed above.
f6_assessments.q2: The information about the metrics to follow up the project and to measure its impact is missing in the proposal. Instead, in the section that asks for them to indicate what will be measured, the proposals have inserted information about the timeline. The proposal has no KPIs clearly indicated, which makes it difficult for the community to audit it. It’s advisable that the team provides clear indicators to measure its progress and also that they explain how they will measure them. Taking this issue into account, a score of 3 is appropriate, as this is the main aspect of the auditability in the assessment.

f6_assessments.q0: Educating and funding female projects is the most groundbreaking initiative we can fund as a Community. If we want to make social and economic transformation, we have to work and empower African women.They are the real unleashed potential. When empowered women will be creative, efficient and transparent newcomers for our Cardano Catalyst. Women grow with a cultural barrier that prohibits us to really develop our intellectual and rational thinking. Getting women into the blockchain technology universe is the biggest social and economic transformation we can enhance. Nevertheless, we should be careful with funding projects that try to only profit from these noble causes. The website and audiovisual content this team shared looked unprofessional and poorly designed. The proposal does effectively address the challenge but further information might be requested in order to guarantee professionalism and real engagement with the problem to solve.
f6_assessments.q1: Team experience is wide in the financial universe but poor or non existing in social entrepreneurism. This might be a big flaw in this proposal. In order to successfully implement the presented plan this team should develop strategic alliances with social targeted organizations and experts. The enormous challenge of educating women should never be taken lightly. Given the information in experience and plan presented it is highly likely this proposal won't be implemented successfully. Big structural changes are needed in order to improve the proposal and deserve funding from our Community.

f6_assessments.q2:
The project is well explained, structured, with a diverse content approach, a well-structured schedule, well-defined time and goals.
However, it was not clear how such success will be observed and measured, I suggest to the proponents some time after the end of the project.
I suggest to the creators of the project, develop some way of evaluating the success and how the content taught is being applied. The volume of projects developed by the students, as well as the evaluation of the importance, functionality of such projects within the Cardano community would be a good thermometer for such an evaluation. Another central point is to observe if the knowledge acquired by the students is being disseminated within the community, since this was one of the central points within the proposal presented
